excerpts: **jsprit** is a java based, open source toolkit for solving rich [**traveling salesman**](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem) (TSP) and [**vehicle routing problems**](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP). It is **lightweight** , **flexible** and **easy-to-use** .

**jsprit** can solve problems with pickups and deliveries, back hauls, heterogeneous fleets, finite and infinite fleets, multiple depots, time windows, open routes, different start and end locations,
multiple capacity dimensions, initial loads, skills ...
Specify your jobs - jsprit allows you to define services (one stop) and shipments (two stops) with multiple capacity dimensions. Additionally, you can set time windows and required skills.

// specify service - which involves one stop  Service service  =   Service.Builder .newInstance( "serviceId" )
          .setName( "myService" )
          .setLocation( Location .newInstance( 5,7 ))
          .addSizeDimension( 0,5 ).addSizeDimension( 1,20 )
          .addRequiredSkill( "electric drill" )
          .setTimeWindow( TimeWindow .newInstance( 20,35 ))
          .build() ; // specify shipment - which involves two stops Shipment shipment  =  Shipment.Builder .newInstance( "shipmentId" )
          .setName( "myShipment" )
          .setPickupLocation( Location .newInstance( 2,7 )).setDeliveryLocation( Location .newInstance( 10,2 ))
          .addSizeDimension( 0,9 ).addSizeDimension( 1,50 )
          .addRequiredSkill( "loading bridge" ).addRequiredSkill( "electric drill" )
          .build() ;

**jsprit** allows you to define additional stateful and stateless constraints to
account for the richness of your problem.

excerpts:
Vroom is an open-source route optimization engine written in C++20
that solves complex [vehicle routing problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP)
in milliseconds.
Vroom solves several well-known types of vehicle routing problems
(VRP).
TSP (travelling salesman problem)
CVRP (capacitated VRP)
VRPTW (VRP with time windows)
MDHVRPTW (multi-depot heterogeneous vehicle VRPTW)
PDPTW (pickup-and-delivery problem with TW)
Vroom solves all of the above routing problems at the same time — and
delivers the optimized route in milliseconds, even when complex
variables are involved.
Vroom works out-of-the-box on top of several open-source routing
engines.
[OSRM](http://project-osrm.org/)
[Openrouteservice](https://openrouteservice.org/)
[Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla)
Vroom can also use a custom cost matrix computed from any other
source.
Delivery/pickup amounts on arbitrary number of metrics
Service time windows
Service duration
Skills
Priority

excerpts: OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.
citations.title: Comparing VRP Solvers: OR-Tools, OptaPlanner, & SaaS APIs

It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.

excerpts:
Vroom is an open-source route optimization engine written in C++20
that solves complex [vehicle routing problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP)
in milliseconds.
Vroom solves several well-known types of vehicle routing problems
(VRP).
TSP (travelling salesman problem)
CVRP (capacitated VRP)
VRPTW (VRP with time windows)
MDHVRPTW (multi-depot heterogeneous vehicle VRPTW)
PDPTW (pickup-and-delivery problem with TW)
Vroom solves all of the above routing problems at the same time — and
delivers the optimized route in milliseconds, even when complex
variables are involved.
Vroom works out-of-the-box on top of several open-source routing
engines.
[OSRM](http://project-osrm.org/)
[Openrouteservice](https://openrouteservice.org/)
[Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla)
Vroom can also use a custom cost matrix computed from any other
source.
Delivery/pickup amounts on arbitrary number of metrics
Service time windows
Service duration
Skills
Priority
Capacity on arbitrary number of metrics
Skills
Working hours
Driver breaks
Start and end defined on a per-vehicle basis
Start and end can be different
Open trip optimization (only start or only end defined)
Service time windows

Working hours
Driver breaks

excerpts:
Scheduling policies in Salesforce Field Service define the rules and objectives
(scheduling priorities) for assigning work to service resources. These policies optimize
resource allocation by considering factors such as resource skills, job proximity, and
urgency, to make sure the right person is assigned to the right job efficiently. By
considering scheduling preferences such as minimizing travel time, scheduling as early as
possible, and prioritizing preferred resources, scheduling policies improve operational
efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Work rules help you refine the list of candidates for a service appointment. You can use
work rules to set specific criteria and filter out service resources that don’t meet your
needs.
Service objectives reflect your business’s scheduling priorities. You can weight each
objective to indicate its level of importance.
Note The Service Resource Availability work rule, and the Earliest Start Permitted and Due Date
Match Time work rules are mandatory for all scheduling policies.
Create and manage scheduling policies from Guided Setup or the Scheduling Policies tab. To
open Guided Setup, from the App Launcher, find and open the **Field Service Admin** app. Click **Field Service Settings** | **Go to Guided Setup** | **Customize Scheduling Policies** . Check your page layout settings before you begin; sometimes fields need to
be added to your layout.
In scheduling policies, you set weights to service objectives. These weights represent the importance of each objective when the engine generates an optimal schedule. You can fine-tune the weights through an iterative tuning process to set weight values in your scheduling policy that closely align with your business KPIs.
citations.title: Create and Manage Field Service Scheduling Policies

excerpts: Each scheduling policy is made up of work rules and service objectives. **Work rules** determine which candidates can complete the job. Do the candidates have the required skills? Are they available in the right territory at the right time? These kinds of questions eliminate unqualified candidates.

When you have a list of qualified candidates, **service objectives** use your business priorities to choose the best candidate for the job. For example, if your top priority is to minimize travel, the qualified candidate closest to the job site is the best choice.
In this unit, Maria learned that scheduling policies are made up of strictly enforced work rules and weighted service objectives.

Work rules assess mobile workers in a similar way. If a work rule specifies the Los Angeles territory, the scheduler asks: Does the candidate work in the Los Angeles territory? If no, they fail. If yes, they pass and are considered for a Los Angeles job.

excerpts: Each scheduling policy is made up of work rules and service objectives. **Work rules** determine which candidates can complete the job. Do the candidates have the required skills? Are they available in the right territory at the right time? These kinds of questions eliminate unqualified candidates.

When you have a list of qualified candidates, **service objectives** use your business priorities to choose the best candidate for the job. For example, if your top priority is to minimize travel, the qualified candidate closest to the job site is the best choice.
In this unit, Maria learned that scheduling policies are made up of strictly enforced work rules and weighted service objectives.

Work rules assess mobile workers in a similar way. If a work rule specifies the Los Angeles territory, the scheduler asks: Does the candidate work in the Los Angeles territory? If no, they fail. If yes, they pass and are considered for a Los Angeles job.
Does the candidate have the necessary skills to complete the job? If no, they fail and aren’t considered for the job. If yes, the candidate passes and the scheduler moves on to the next rule.

The managed package ships with several work rules. Some rules apply to candidates. For example, Match Skills ensures that a candidate is qualified to do the job. And Required Resource ensures that the specified worker works with a certain customer.
Some rules apply to time. Service Appointment Visiting Hours makes sure that the appointment is scheduled during a customer’s visiting hours.

excerpts:
Service Resource Availability is an Apex work rule type that ensures that a service
resource is available to perform a service appointment. You can schedule breaks
automatically, account for travel time, or set up short breaks between service appointments.
A work rule of this type is mandatory for all scheduling policies to ensure that both
resource absences and availability are respected during the scheduling process.

excerpts: Home Health Care Routing and Scheduling Problems (HHCRSP) have received a lot of attention lately  [5 ]. This problem involves allocating nurses to patients, scheduling working times, and establishing travel routes under some governmental regulations and industry-specific constraints  [5 ].
We consider the time window a hard constraint, i.e., a nurse must wait if he or she arrives early at the patient's home, and arrivals after the time window are not allowed.

As a legislative requirement, each nurse must have a 1-h lunch break at certain time intervals. For the sake of simplicity, since we do not know the exact location of nurses when they take a lunch break, we assume that the nurses will go to the nearest facility for lunch or bring their meal and that the 1-h lunch break will include both travel times and meal time.

excerpts: The purpose of this paper is to propose a literature survey on “Home Health Care problems” dealing with routing and scheduling, to provide an overview of the constraints and objectives addressed by Operations Research and Industrial Engineering tools for both theoretical and practical HHC problems.

We focus not only on the methods used in the different papers studied but also and mainly on constraints and objectives which are specific to the HHC context, particularly highlighting the uncertain and dynamic aspects present in a growing number of papers.

Other reviews are more focused on the HHC Routing and Scheduling Problem (HHCRSP): Fikar and Hirsch (2017) provided a comprehensive overview of existing works up to 2015 in the field of HHC, focusing on the most common parameters in routing and scheduling problems.

Our purpose here is to identify the constraints and objectives specific to routing and scheduling problems in the HHC context, which have given rise to the development of methods or softwares based on Operations Research (OR) and/or Industrial Engineering (IE) tools.

excerpts: • This review investigates recent work on home health care routing and scheduling.

In home health care (HHC) operations, nurses are scheduled and routed to perform various services at clients' homes. excerpts:
Scheduling policies in Salesforce Field Service define the rules and objectives
(scheduling priorities) for assigning work to service resources. These policies optimize
resource allocation by considering factors such as resource skills, job proximity, and
urgency, to make sure the right person is assigned to the right job efficiently. By
considering scheduling preferences such as minimizing travel time, scheduling as early as
possible, and prioritizing preferred resources, scheduling policies improve operational
efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Work rules help you refine the list of candidates for a service appointment. You can use
work rules to set specific criteria and filter out service resources that don’t meet your
needs.
Service objectives reflect your business’s scheduling priorities. You can weight each
objective to indicate its level of importance.
Note The Service Resource Availability work rule, and the Earliest Start Permitted and Due Date
Match Time work rules are mandatory for all scheduling policies.
In scheduling policies, you set weights to service objectives. These weights represent the importance of each objective when the engine generates an optimal schedule. You can fine-tune the weights through an iterative tuning process to set weight values in your scheduling policy that closely align with your business KPIs.
citations.title: Create and Manage Field Service Scheduling Policies

excerpts: Each scheduling policy is made up of work rules and service objectives. **Work rules** determine which candidates can complete the job. Do the candidates have the required skills? Are they available in the right territory at the right time? These kinds of questions eliminate unqualified candidates.

When you have a list of qualified candidates, **service objectives** use your business priorities to choose the best candidate for the job. For example, if your top priority is to minimize travel, the qualified candidate closest to the job site is the best choice.
In this unit, Maria learned that scheduling policies are made up of strictly enforced work rules and weighted service objectives.

Work rules assess mobile workers in a similar way. If a work rule specifies the Los Angeles territory, the scheduler asks: Does the candidate work in the Los Angeles territory? If no, they fail. If yes, they pass and are considered for a Los Angeles job.

excerpts:
Vroom is an open-source route optimization engine written in C++20
that solves complex [vehicle routing problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP)
in milliseconds.
Vroom solves several well-known types of vehicle routing problems
(VRP).
TSP (travelling salesman problem)
CVRP (capacitated VRP)
VRPTW (VRP with time windows)
MDHVRPTW (multi-depot heterogeneous vehicle VRPTW)
PDPTW (pickup-and-delivery problem with TW)
Vroom solves all of the above routing problems at the same time — and
delivers the optimized route in milliseconds, even when complex
variables are involved.
Vroom works out-of-the-box on top of several open-source routing
engines.
[OSRM](http://project-osrm.org/)
[Openrouteservice](https://openrouteservice.org/)
[Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla)
Vroom can also use a custom cost matrix computed from any other
source.

resource is available to perform a service appointment. You can schedule breaks

resource absences and availability are respected during the scheduling process.

excerpts: In home health care (HHC) operations, nurses are scheduled and routed to perform various services at clients' homes. As this often requires a combination of vehicle routing and scheduling approaches, resulting optimization problems are complex and, hence, of high interest to stakeholders such as researchers, practitioners and policy-makers.

Considering a wide range of regulative and operational constraints, HHC planners assign nurses to clients and schedule working times. Additionally, travel routes and arrival times of nurses to each client have to be planned.
• This review investigates recent work on home health care routing and scheduling.

excerpts: **jsprit** is a java based, open source toolkit for solving rich [**traveling salesman**](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem) (TSP) and [**vehicle routing problems**](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP). It is **lightweight** , **flexible** and **easy-to-use** .

**jsprit** can solve problems with pickups and deliveries, back hauls, heterogeneous fleets, finite and infinite fleets, multiple depots, time windows, open routes, different start and end locations,
multiple capacity dimensions, initial loads, skills ...

**jsprit** allows you to define additional stateful and stateless constraints to
account for the richness of your problem.
Specify your jobs - jsprit allows you to define services (one stop) and shipments (two stops) with multiple capacity dimensions. Additionally, you can set time windows and required skills.

// specify service - which involves one stop  Service service  =   Service.Builder .newInstance( "serviceId" )
          .setName( "myService" )
          .setLocation( Location .newInstance( 5,7 ))
          .addSizeDimension( 0,5 ).addSizeDimension( 1,20 )
          .addRequiredSkill( "electric drill" )
          .setTimeWindow( TimeWindow .newInstance( 20,35 ))
          .build() ; // specify shipment - which involves two stops Shipment shipment  =  Shipment.Builder .newInstance( "shipmentId" )
          .setName( "myShipment" )
          .setPickupLocation( Location .newInstance( 2,7 )).setDeliveryLocation( Location .newInstance( 10,2 ))
          .addSizeDimension( 0,9 ).addSizeDimension( 1,50 )
          .addRequiredSkill( "loading bridge" ).addRequiredSkill( "electric drill" )
          .build() ;

excerpts: Each scheduling policy is made up of work rules and service objectives. **Work rules** determine which candidates can complete the job. Do the candidates have the required skills? Are they available in the right territory at the right time? These kinds of questions eliminate unqualified candidates.

When you have a list of qualified candidates, **service objectives** use your business priorities to choose the best candidate for the job. For example, if your top priority is to minimize travel, the qualified candidate closest to the job site is the best choice.

excerpts:
Scheduling policies in Salesforce Field Service define the rules and objectives
(scheduling priorities) for assigning work to service resources. These policies optimize
resource allocation by considering factors such as resource skills, job proximity, and
urgency, to make sure the right person is assigned to the right job efficiently. By
considering scheduling preferences such as minimizing travel time, scheduling as early as
possible, and prioritizing preferred resources, scheduling policies improve operational
efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Work rules help you refine the list of candidates for a service appointment. You can use
work rules to set specific criteria and filter out service resources that don’t meet your
needs.
Service objectives reflect your business’s scheduling priorities. You can weight each
objective to indicate its level of importance.
Note The Service Resource Availability work rule, and the Earliest Start Permitted and Due Date
Match Time work rules are mandatory for all scheduling policies.
Create and manage scheduling policies from Guided Setup or the Scheduling Policies tab. To
open Guided Setup, from the App Launcher, find and open the **Field Service Admin** app. Click **Field Service Settings** | **Go to Guided Setup** | **Customize Scheduling Policies** . Check your page layout settings before you begin; sometimes fields need to
be added to your layout.
In scheduling policies, you set weights to service objectives. These weights represent the importance of each objective when the engine generates an optimal schedule. You can fine-tune the weights through an iterative tuning process to set weight values in your scheduling policy that closely align with your business KPIs.
citations.title: Create and Manage Field Service Scheduling Policies

excerpts: OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

excerpts: OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.

excerpts:
Vroom works out-of-the-box on top of several open-source routing
engines.
[OSRM](http://project-osrm.org/)
[Openrouteservice](https://openrouteservice.org/)
[Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla)
Vroom can also use a custom cost matrix computed from any other
source.
Vroom solves several well-known types of vehicle routing problems
(VRP).
TSP (travelling salesman problem)
CVRP (capacitated VRP)
VRPTW (VRP with time windows)
MDHVRPTW (multi-depot heterogeneous vehicle VRPTW)
PDPTW (pickup-and-delivery problem with TW)
Vroom solves all of the above routing problems at the same time — and
delivers the optimized route in milliseconds, even when complex
variables are involved.
Vroom is an open-source route optimization engine written in C++20
that solves complex [vehicle routing problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP)
in milliseconds.

excerpts:
Scheduling policies in Salesforce Field Service define the rules and objectives
(scheduling priorities) for assigning work to service resources. These policies optimize
resource allocation by considering factors such as resource skills, job proximity, and
urgency, to make sure the right person is assigned to the right job efficiently. By
considering scheduling preferences such as minimizing travel time, scheduling as early as
possible, and prioritizing preferred resources, scheduling policies improve operational
efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Work rules help you refine the list of candidates for a service appointment. You can use
work rules to set specific criteria and filter out service resources that don’t meet your
needs.
Service objectives reflect your business’s scheduling priorities. You can weight each
objective to indicate its level of importance.
Note The Service Resource Availability work rule, and the Earliest Start Permitted and Due Date
Match Time work rules are mandatory for all scheduling policies.
In scheduling policies, you set weights to service objectives. These weights represent the importance of each objective when the engine generates an optimal schedule. You can fine-tune the weights through an iterative tuning process to set weight values in your scheduling policy that closely align with your business KPIs.
citations.title: Create and Manage Field Service Scheduling Policies

excerpts: OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.
citations.title: Comparing VRP Solvers: OR-Tools, OptaPlanner, & SaaS APIs

In scheduling policies, you set weights to service objectives. These weights represent the importance of each objective when the engine generates an optimal schedule. Scheduling policies in Salesforce Field Service define the rules and objectives
(scheduling priorities) for assigning work to service resources. These policies optimize
resource allocation by considering factors such as resource skills, job proximity, and
urgency, to make sure the right person is assigned to the right job efficiently. By
considering scheduling preferences such as minimizing travel time, scheduling as early as
possible, and prioritizing preferred resources, scheduling policies improve operational
efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Work rules help you refine the list of candidates for a service appointment. You can use
work rules to set specific criteria and filter out service resources that don’t meet your
needs.
Service objectives reflect your business’s scheduling priorities. You can weight each
objective to indicate its level of importance.

Match Time work rules are mandatory for all scheduling policies.

excerpts:
Vroom is an open-source route optimization engine written in C++20
that solves complex [vehicle routing problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_routing_problem) (VRP)
in milliseconds.
Vroom solves several well-known types of vehicle routing problems
(VRP).
TSP (travelling salesman problem)
CVRP (capacitated VRP)
VRPTW (VRP with time windows)
MDHVRPTW (multi-depot heterogeneous vehicle VRPTW)
PDPTW (pickup-and-delivery problem with TW)
Vroom solves all of the above routing problems at the same time — and
delivers the optimized route in milliseconds, even when complex
variables are involved.
Vroom works out-of-the-box on top of several open-source routing
engines.
[OSRM](http://project-osrm.org/)
[Openrouteservice](https://openrouteservice.org/)
[Valhalla](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla)
Vroom can also use a custom cost matrix computed from any other
source.
citations.title: GitHub - VROOM-Project/vroom: Vehicle Routing Open-source Optimization Machine

excerpts: OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

OR-Tools excels in performance and scalability. It can handle large datasets with hundreds of nodes while maintaining low runtime. Its ability to achieve near-optimal solutions with minimal optimization gaps makes it a reliable choice for solving VRP challenges. The library's open-source nature allows you to customize it for specific needs, giving you full control over the optimization process.

OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.
citations.title: Comparing VRP Solvers: OR-Tools, OptaPlanner, & SaaS APIs

excerpts: OptaPlanner excels in handling complex datasets. Its incremental score calculation method significantly improves performance. Instead of recalculating the entire score, it evaluates only the changes. This approach speeds up the process and ensures quicker solutions. For large problems, OptaPlanner maintains high score calculation speeds, often exceeding [1,000 evaluations per second](https://www.optaplanner.org/docs/optaplanner/latest/score-calculation/score-calculation.html) . This makes it a reliable choice for solving intricate routing problems.

OptaPlanner is an open-source tool designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It uses advanced algorithms like metaheuristics to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges. You can customize its solver configurations to match your specific needs. This flexibility makes it a great choice for businesses with unique routing requirements.

OR-Tools, developed by Google, is a powerful open-source library designed to solve optimization problems, including [vehicle routing](https://www.singdata.com/customers/route-optimization-101-algorithms-delivery/) . It supports a wide range of VRP variants, such as the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). You can use its advanced algorithms, like Local Search and Large Neighborhood Search (LNS), to find efficient solutions for complex logistics challenges.

One standout feature is its flexibility in defining constraints. For example, you can use the `add_multiple_circuit` constraint to enhance optimization strategies. OR-Tools also supports the Miller-Tucker-Zemlin (MTZ) formulation, which can improve performance for specific VRP types. These features make it a versatile tool for tackling diverse routing problems.

excerpts: In home health care (HHC) operations, nurses are scheduled and routed to perform various services at clients' homes. As this often requires a combination of vehicle routing and scheduling approaches, resulting optimization problems are complex and, hence, of high interest to stakeholders such as researchers, practitioners and policy-makers.

Considering a wide range of regulative and operational constraints, HHC planners assign nurses to clients and schedule working times. Additionally, travel routes and arrival times of nurses to each client have to be planned.
• This review investigates recent work on home health care routing and scheduling.

executive_summary.description: A high-level overview of the landscape for home care and field service scheduling optimization, summarizing the trade-offs between using commercial platforms, open-source solvers, or building a custom solution.

key_recommendations.description: Actionable recommendations for an organization looking to implement or improve their scheduling optimization, focusing on how to avoid 'reinventing the wheel' by leveraging existing solutions and best practices.

problem_definition_hhcrsp.description: An explanation of the Home Health Care Routing and Scheduling Problem (HHCRSP) as a complex variant of the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP), detailing its unique challenges and why it is considered an NP-hard optimization problem.

platform_name.description: The name of the commercial platform (e.g., Timefold, Microsoft Dynamics 365).

key_products_or_modules.description: The main products or modules offered for scheduling (e.g., Employee Shift Scheduling, Field Service Routing, Resource Scheduling Optimization).

rule_definition_methodology.description: The approach the platform uses to define optimization rules (e.g., Constraints and Objectives, Work Rules and Service Objectives).

core_technology_and_origin.description: Information about the underlying technology or its history (e.g., Fork of OptaPlanner, Built on Universal Resource Scheduling).

commercial_solutions_overview.description: Details on commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) solutions for scheduling optimization. This will include platforms like Timefold, Microsoft Dynamics 365 Field Service, and Salesforce Field Service, covering their core functionalities, target users, and approach to defining rules and objectives.

solver_name.description: The name of the open-source solver (e.g., Google OR-Tools, VROOM).

primary_language.description: The primary programming language the solver is written in (e.g., C++, Java).

license.description: The open-source license under which the solver is distributed (e.g., Apache 2.0, BSD).

supported_problem_types.description: The types of vehicle routing or scheduling problems it supports (e.g., CVRP, VRPTW, TSP).

key_features.description: Notable features such as support for skills, time windows, breaks, or specific algorithms.

open_source_solvers_overview.description: Information on popular open-source optimization solvers. This will include libraries like Google OR-Tools, VROOM, and jsprit, detailing their programming languages, key features, supported problem types (e.g., CVRP, VRPTW), and licensing.

solver_comparison.description: A comparative analysis of the different solver options, weighing factors such as performance, flexibility, total cost of ownership (licensing vs. development effort), community support, and ease of use for commercial vs. open-source solutions.

timefold_platform_deep_dive.description: A detailed look at the Timefold platform, covering its origins as a fork of OptaPlanner, its key products like Employee Shift Scheduling (ESS) and Field Service Routing (FSR), performance benchmarks, and specific features relevant to home care and field service.

demand_supply_matching_strategies.description: An explanation of how scheduling systems match supply (caregivers, technicians, shifts, vehicles) with demand (patient visits, service jobs, coverage requirements). This includes modeling techniques for skills, availability, and location.

constraint_name.description: The name of the constraint (e.g., Skill Matching, Time Windows).

description.description: A brief explanation of what the constraint enforces.

constraint_type.description: Indicates if the constraint is typically treated as a hard (must be met) or soft (desirable to meet) rule.

example_application.description: An example of how the constraint is used in home care or field service.

common_optimization_constraints.description: A list of common hard and soft constraints used in scheduling optimization. Examples include caregiver skills, patient time windows, working hours, break times, workload balancing, continuity of care, and resource territory.

objective_name.description: The name of the business objective (e.g., Minimize Travel Time, Maximize Resource Utilization).

description.description: A brief explanation of the business goal the objective represents.

measurement.description: How the objective is typically measured or quantified (e.g., Total travel minutes, number of visits per day).

common_optimization_objectives.description: A list of typical business goals or objectives that the optimization engine aims to achieve. Examples include minimizing total travel time/cost, maximizing the number of completed visits, maximizing resource utilization, and prioritizing high-urgency tasks.

hybrid_workflow_approach.description: A description of the 'shift-then-route' hybrid workflow. This explains the two-stage process of first generating employee shifts (ESS) and then optimizing the daily routes for those shifts (FSR), and why this approach is common.

google_or_tools_details.description: Specific details about Google's OR-Tools, including its strengths in solving Vehicle Routing Problems (VRP), its support for various constraints, its use of algorithms like Local Search, and its suitability for users with programming expertise.

vroom_solver_details.description: Specific details about the VROOM (Vehicle Routing Open-source Optimization Machine) solver, including its C++ architecture, its reliance on routing engines like OSRM, and its support for features like skills, time windows, and driver breaks.

jsprit_solver_details.description: Specific details about the jsprit solver, highlighting its nature as a Java-based toolkit for rich VRPs, its flexibility, and its built-in support for concepts like heterogeneous fleets, multiple depots, time windows, and skills.

industry_best_practices.description: A summary of established best practices in the home care and field service industries for implementing and managing scheduling optimization, drawing from both academic literature and commercial product documentation.

implementation_guidelines.description: Practical advice for getting started with a scheduling optimization project, including data preparation, defining business rules, choosing between a platform and a library, and structuring a proof-of-concept (POC).
